abstract.p: This worksheet is meant to be used in class. You should be working in groups or individually depending on the instructions from your teacher.
You can submit responses any number of times.

Remember, the point is that you learn from your mistakes and with the help of your peers, so make sure you reflect on incorrect answers and try again with your new understanding. If you can't figure it out, ask your teacher, or bring up your strategy in a whole class discussion. This will allow you to get as much as possible out of the activity.

ul.li: Solving systems of equations in two variables

exercises.title: Exercises
exercises.p: The following exercises test your knowledge of the prerequisites for this section.

statement.p: Solve the system of equations

hint.p: Can you solve each equation separately? If so, then this is a simple system to solve!

solution.p: The first equation gives -2=2x, so x=-1. The second one is equivalent to 4=8y, so y=1/2.

statement.p: Solve the system of equations

hint.p: Try adding or subtracting the two equations to find an equation with only one variable.

solution.p: If we add these two equations together, the 4y cancels giving 14x=0, so x=0. Setting x=0 in either of the two equations gives y=-1. Thus, the only solution is x=0 and y=-1.

statement.p: Solve the system of equations
There may be multiple answers. Make sure you input all of them.

hint.p: Any pair of values (x,y) which is a solution to the system must satisfy both equations. In particular, the y-coordinates have to equal at the same time x^2+3x-5 and x+3. Use this to find the only possible values for x for which (x,y) could be a solution.

solution.p: Any pair of values (x,y) which is a solution must satisfy both equations. In particular, the y-coordinates of any solution have to both equal x^2+3x-5 and x+3. Thus, we have x^2+3x-5=x+3, which has solutions x=-4 and x=2. These are the only values of x for which (x,y) can satisfy both equations in the system of equations. Setting x=-4 in either of the two equations we find y=-1, so (x,y)=(-4,-1) is a solution (the only one with x=-4). Setting x=3 in either of the two equations we find y=5, so (x,y)=(2,5) is the only other solution.
Thus, the only solutions are (x,y)=(-4,-1) and (x,y)=(2,5)

statement.p: Solve the system of equations
There may be multiple answers. Make sure you input all of them.

hint.p: Note that you can isolate y in both equations. Note that any pair of values (x,y) which is a solution to the system must satisfy both equations. Use this to find the only possible values for x for which (x,y) could be a solution.

solution.p: Thus, we must have x^2-24=x-12, which has solutions x=-3 and x=4. These are the only values of x for which (x,y) can satisfy both equations in the system of equations. Setting x=-3 in either of the two equations we find y=-15, so (x,y)=(-3,-15) is a solution (the only one with x=-3). Setting x=4 in either of the two equations we find y=-8, so (x,y)=(4,-8) is the only other solution.

statement.p: Solve the system of equations
There may be multiple answers. Make sure you input all of them.

hint.p: Note that you can solve for y in the second equation. Since any pair of values (x,y) which is a solution to the system must satisfy both equations, then the y-value of any solution must be what the second equation tells you it should be. Plug this into the first equation to find the only possible values for x for which (x,y) is a solution.

solution.p:
Solving for y in the second equation gives y=-x^2/2. Any pair of values (x,y) which is a solution to the system must satisfy y=-x^2/2, and so we can plug this into the first equation, giving
2x\left(-\frac{x^2}{2} \right)+\left(-\frac{x^2}{2} \right)\amp =\amp 0 -x^3-\frac{x^2}{2}\amp =\amp 0 -\frac{1}{2} x^2 (2 x + 1)\amp =\amp 0
so x=0 or x=-1/2. These are the only two possible values of x for which (x,y) may be a solution of the system (for some y). Setting x=0 in the second equation of the system we find y=0, so (x,y)=(0,0) is a solution (the only one with x=0). Setting x=-1/2 in the second equation of the system we find y=-1/8, so (x,y)=(-1/2,-1/8) is the only other solution.

statement.p: Solve the system of equations
There may be multiple answers. Make sure you input all of them.

hint.p: A solution to the system is a pair of values (x,y) which makes both equations true. Note that you can factor out a y in the second equation. What does the factored form tell you about the solutions to the second equation?

solution.p: Factoring out a 2y in the second equation gives 2y(1+x)=0, so either 2y=0 or 1+x=0 (or both). This shows that any solution (x,y) to the system must have y=0 or x=-1. Setting y=0 in the first equation gives \[10x+6x^2=0,\] which has solutions x=0 or x=-5/3. Thus, (x,y)=(0,0) and (x,y)=(-5/3,0) are two solutions (the only solutions with y=0). Setting x=-1 in the first equation gives -4+y^2=0, so y=\pm 2. Thus, (x,y)=(-1,-2) and (x,y)=(-1,2) are two more solutions (the only solutions with x=-1).
The solutions to the system are (0,0), (-5/3,0), (-1,-2) and (-1,2).

statement.p: Find the partial derivative f_x for

hint.p: When finding a partial derivative all other variables are treated as constants.

solution.p:
When we differentiate with respect to x, we think of y as a constant. Thus,
f_x(x,y)\amp=\amp \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(x^2y-2x^2+3xy^2\right) \amp=\amp \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(x^2y\right)-\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(2x^2\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(3xy^2\right) \amp =\amp 2xy - 4x + 3y^2

statement.p: Find the partial derivative g_y for

hint.p: When finding a partial derivative all other variables are treated as constants.

solution.p:
When we differentiate with respect to y, we think of x as a constant. Thus,
g_y(x,y)\amp =\amp \frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(3y-5x^2y+6xy^2+4\right) \amp =\amp \frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(3y\right)-\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(5x^2y\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial y} \left(6xy^2\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(4\right) \amp =\amp 3-5x^2+12xy

ul.li: (a,b) is a local maximum of f(x,y) if f(a,b)\geq f(x,y) for all (x,y) near (a,b) . (a,b) is a local minimum of f(x,y) if f(a,b)\leq f(x,y) for all (x,y) near (a,b) .
A critical point of a function f(x,y) is a point where \nabla f(x,y)=\vec{0} or where \nabla f(x,y) is undefined.
Any local minima or maxima of f(x,y) must occur at a critical point of f(x,y) .

li.p: The nature of a critical point can be determined using the Second Derivative Test. Specifically, let H_f=\left[ \begin{array}{cc} f_{xx} \amp f_{xy} \\ f_{yx} \amp f_{yy} \end{array}\right] and let D=\det{(H_f)} (H_f is called the Hessian matrix of f(x,y) ). If (a,b) is a critical point of f(x,y) , then:

ol.li: if D(a,b)\gt 0 and f_{xx}\gt 0 , (a,b) is a local minimum
if D(a,b)>0 and f_{xx}\lt 0 , (a,b) is a local maximum
if D(a,b)\lt 0 , then (a,b) is neither a maximum or a minimum
if D(a,b)=0 , the test is inconclusive.

li.p: Note: If the test is inconclusive or \nabla f is undefined, we need to use some other method.

ul.li: Other methods to determine the nature of a critical point of f(x,y) include looking at its graph or a contour diagram.

subsection.title: Goals
subsection.p: After completing your work on this section, you should be able to:

ul.li: Define what it means for a point (a,b) to be a local minimum or maximum of a function f(x,y)
Define and find the critical points of a function of two variables
Recognize minima, maxima, and saddle points on the graph of a function or from a contour diagram
Classify critical points as minima, maxima, or saddle points using the second derivative test
Recognize when the second derivative test is inconclusive or cannot be used and use other methods to determine the nature of a critical point

hint.p: What is true about \nabla g(x,y) at a critical point?

solution.p:
A critical point of a function g(x,y) is a point where \nabla g(x,y)=\vec{0} or where \nabla g(x,y) is undefined. The partial derivatives
g_x(x,y)\amp =10x+4y+4 g_y(x,y)\amp = 4x-4y-4,
show that \nabla g(x,y) is defined everywhere, and \nabla g(x,y)=\vec{0} only at the points which are solutions the system of equations
10x+4y+4 \amp = 0 4x-4y-4 \amp = 0.
If we add these two equations together, the 4y will cancel giving 14x=0, so x=0. Setting x=0 in either of the two equations gives y=-1. Thus, the only solution to the system is (x,y)=(0,-1). Thus, the only critical point is (0,-1).

statement.p: Find the critical points of the following function.

hint.p: What is true about \nabla h(x,y) at a critical point?

solution.p:
A critical point of a function h(x,y) is a point where \nabla h(x,y)=\vec{0} or where \nabla h(x,y) is undefined. The partial derivatives
h_x(x,y)\amp= 6 x^2 + 10 x + y^2 h_y(x,y)\amp= 2xy+2y,
show that \nabla h(x,y) is defined everywhere, and \nabla h(x,y)=\vec{0} only at the points which are solutions the system of equations
6 x^2 + 10 x + y^2 \amp= 0 2xy+2y \amp = 0.
Factoring out a 2y in the second equation gives 2y(1+x)=0, so either 2y=0 or 1+x=0 (or both). This shows that any solution (x,y) to the system must have y=0 or x=-1. Setting y=0 in the first equation gives \[10x+6x^2=0,\] which has solutions x=0 or x=-5/3. Thus, (x,y)=(0,0) and (x,y)=(-5/3,0) are two solutions (the only solutions with y=0). Setting x=-1 in the first equation gives -4+y^2=0, so y=\pm 2. Thus, (x,y)=(-1,-2) and (x,y)=(-1,2) are two more solutions (the only solutions with x=-1).
Therefore, the solutions to the system are (0,0), (-5/3,0), (-1,-2) and (-1,2). These are the critical points.

section.p: The following is the contour diagram for the function g(x,y)=2x^3+xy^2+5x^2+y^2. Use it to help classify its critical points.

hint.p: When you move away form the points, do the values of the contours always increase or decrease? Or are there directions in which they increase and others in which they decrease?

solution.p: When you move away form the (-5/3,0) in any direction, the contour values seem to always decrease. This indicates that (-5/3,0) is a maximum. A similar reasoning indicates that (0,0) is a minimum (all contour values increase away from the point).

Regarding the point (-1,2) note that if you move away from the point in the -\vec{i}+\vec{j} direction (or its direct opposite, the \vec{i}-\vec{j} direction) the values of the contours seem to decrease. However, if you move away from the point in the \vec{i}+\vec{j} direction (or its direct opposite, the -\vec{i}-\vec{j} direction) the values of the contours seem to increase. This indicates that (-1,2) is a saddle point. A similar reasoning shows that (-1,-2) is also a saddle point.

solution.p:
A critical point of a function f(x,y) is a point where 
abla f(x,y)=\vec{0} or where

f_x(x,y)\amp = -2-2x f_y(x,y)\amp = 4-8y,
show that

We compute D D=\det \pmatrix{f_{xx} \amp f_{xy} \\ f_{yx} \amp f_{yy}}=\det \pmatrix{-2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -8}=16, and see that D\gt 0 (at any point so in particular at (-1,1/2)), so we see that (-1,1/2) is a local maximum or a local minimum. To figure out which one it is, we can look at, for example, the concavity in x-direction by computing f_{xx}(-1,1/2) which gives f_{xx}(-1,1/2)=-2\lt 0. A critical point of a function h(x,y) is a point where

h_x(x,y)\amp = 6 x^2 + 10 x + y^2 h_y(x,y)\amp = 2xy+2y ,

Factoring out a 2y in the second equation gives 2y(1+x)=0, so either 2y=0 or 1+x=0 (or both). This shows that any solution (x,y) to the system must have y=0 or x=-1. li.p: Are the following statements true or false?

ol.li: The only places a local minima or maxima can occur are where \nabla f=\vec{0}
Provided \nabla f\neq \vec{0} , the second derivative test can always be used to determine the nature of a critical point
Explain geometrically why, if f_x and f_y are defined, they both have to be zero at a minimum or maximum.
What do you expect a contour diagram to look like close to a minimum or maximum? What about close to a saddle point?
If two contours cross at a point (a,b) , does this mean it has to be a critical point? If so, does it have to be a saddle?
